Achieving Linear Speedup in Asynchronous Federated Learning with Heterogeneous Clients

Xiaolu Wang, Zijian Li, , Shi Jin, , and Jun Zhang X. Wang, Z. Li, and J. Zhang are with the Department of Electronic and Computer Engineering, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Hong Kong SAR, China (E-mail: eexlwang@ust.hk, zijian.li@connect.ust.hk, eejzhang@ust.hk). S. Jin is with the National Mobile Communications Research Laboratory, Southeast University, Nanjing, China (E-mail: jinshi@seu.edu.cn). (Corresponding author: Jun Zhang.)
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is an emerging distributed training paradigm that aims to learn a common global model without exchanging or transferring the data that are stored locally at different clients. The Federated Averaging (FedAvg)-based algorithms have gained substantial popularity in FL to reduce the communication overhead, where each client conducts multiple localized iterations before communicating with a central server. In this paper, we focus on FL where the clients have diverse computation and/or communication capabilities. Under this circumstance, FedAvg can be less efficient since it requires all clients that participate in the global aggregation in a round to initiate iterations from the latest global model, and thus the synchronization among fast clients and straggler clients can severely slow down the overall training process. To address this issue, we propose an efficient asynchronous federated learning (AFL) framework called Delayed Federated Averaging (DeFedAvg). In DeFedAvg, the clients are allowed to perform local training with different stale global models at their own paces. Theoretical analyses demonstrate that DeFedAvg achieves asymptotic convergence rates that are on par with the results of FedAvg for solving nonconvex problems. More importantly, DeFedAvg is the first AFL algorithm that provably achieves the desirable linear speedup property, which indicates its high scalability. Additionally, we carry out extensive numerical experiments using real datasets to validate the efficiency and scalability of our approach when training deep neural networks.

Index Terms:
Asynchronous federated learning, edge machine learning, distributed optimization, system heterogeneity, linear speedup.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a distributed machine learning paradigm that enables training models across a network of clients (such as wireless sensors, mobile terminals, and edge devices) while keeping the data localized, under the orchestration of a central server [1]. FL is particularly useful in mobile edge computing and Internet of Things (IoT) environments where the devices generate data locally. For example, FL enables real-time analytics and decision-making at the edge, empowering intelligent traffic management, environmental monitoring, and resource optimization in the context of smart cities [2]. Besides, in industrial IoT, FL facilitates collaborative learning among sensors and devices, enabling anomaly detection, task scheduling, etc. [3].

In classical algorithms for distributed machine learning, e.g., parallel stochastic gradient descent (SGD), multiple training examples are processed simultaneously across different clients [4]. However, it may induce substantial communication overhead, as every local gradient needs to be sent to the server. Considering that federated networks may encompass an extensive array of clients, the communication within such networks can be significantly slower than local computation by several orders of magnitude, due to constrained resources like bandwidth, energy, and power [5].

To address the pivotal communication bottleneck in FL, FedAvg [6], which is also called local SGD [7], performs multiple iterations locally at the clients before communicating with the server. Compared with parallel SGD, the frequency of communication in FedAvg can be reduced by allowing local training in each client. An important feature of FedAvg is that it is able to achieve linear speedup with respect to (wrt) the number of participating clients in each communication round [8], meaning that the communication overhead required to achieve a certain level of optimization accuracy decreases linearly with the increase in computational resources. Linear speedup is a highly desirable property in distributed learning, since it signifies the scalability of the optimization process as more clients are added.

Typically, FL is faced with the challenge of system heterogeneity, which refers to the variation in hardware, software, and network conditions across the participating clients [9]. In spite of the favorable practical and theoretical properties of FedAvg, a major challenge concerns the time needed to synchronize a communication round. In the presence of system heterogeneity, there can be large variations in the computation and communication speeds of different clients [10, 5]. As a consequence, the time needed for a round is conditioned to the slowest client, while the faster clients stay idle once they send their local updates to the server. This phenomenon, known as the straggler effect, can significantly slow down the overall training process. Motivated by this, a multitude of studies have focused on developing asynchronous federated learning (AFL) algorithms, where the clients are allowed to initiate local training at different times, thereby enhancing the system performance. Nevertheless, the introduction of asynchrony adds complexity to the learning dynamics, and existing AFL algorithms have not rigorously attained the desirable linear speedup property. This limitation can potentially restrict the scalability of these AFL algorithms. Therefore, it is imperative to address the following question: Is it possible to develop an AFL method that effectively mitigates the straggler effect while maintaining the linear speedup property observed in synchronous FL?

1.1 Our Contributions

In this paper, we provide an affirmative answer to the aforementioned question. Specifically, we propose an AFL framework, called Delayed Federated Averaging (DeFedAvg), for efficient FL under system heterogeneity. To fit the FL scenarios with non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) and independent and identically distributed (IID) data distributions across clients, we consider two types of DeFedAvg, i.e., DeFedAvg-nIID and DeFedAvg-IID. To outline, DeFedAvg possesses the following main characteristics:

  • •

    Partial Participation. Only a subset of clients participate in the global iteration in each round. In DeFedAvg-nIID, the server sample n𝑛n clients uniformly random with replacement; while in DeFedAvg-IID, the server collects and aggregates these local model updates whenever n𝑛n of them become available.

  • •

    Delayed Local Training. The clients keep receiving the latest global models from the server and store them into their receive buffers with overwriting permitted. They then perform local training, regardless of their participation in the global iteration. The server accepts delayed updates without waiting for the participating clients to train using the latest global model.

  • •

    Asynchronous Clients. Once a client completes its local training, the delayed update is either stored in the send buffer until it is selected by the server (in DeFedAvg-nIID) or directly uploaded to the server (in DeFedAvg-IID). The client then initiates new local training using the global model stored in its receive buffer, independent of the computation/communication states of other clients.

In a nutshell, DeFedAvg enhances the training efficiency compared to traditional FedAvg by reducing the server’s waiting time and the clients’ idle time.

On the theoretical side, we provide the convergence analyses of DeFedAvg for solving smooth and nonconvex objective functions, including deep neural networks that are of particular interest. Our analyses reveal that DeFedAvg-nIID (respectively, DeFedAvg-IID) converges at a rate of 𝒪​(1/n​T+1/K​T)𝒪1𝑛𝑇1𝐾𝑇\mathcal{O}({1}/{\sqrt{nT}}+{1}/{KT}) (respectively, 𝒪​(1/n​K​T+1/K​T)𝒪1𝑛𝐾𝑇1𝐾𝑇\mathcal{O}({1}/{\sqrt{nKT}}+{1}/{KT})) for sufficiently large T𝑇T, where n𝑛n is the number of participating clients in each round, K𝐾K is the number of local updates in each round, and T𝑇T is the total number of communication rounds. These imply the linear speedup property wrt n𝑛n. Our results demonstrate that incorporating delayed updates in local training effectively mitigates the straggler effect without sacrificing the asymptotic convergence rates. To our knowledge, we are the first to achieve the linear speedup guarantees in AFL. Furthermore, our theoretical findings for DeFedAvg can be reduced to the latest results for classic FedAvg and asynchronous SGD under different specific setups, adding to the versatility and applicability of our technical contributions.

On the empirical side, we validate the effectiveness of DeFedAvg through extensive experiments involving the training of neural networks on real-world datasets. We compare its performance with that of the latest distributed learning algorithms, serving as a benchmark for evaluation. These experiments provide empirical evidence for the benefits and advantages of DeFedAvg in practical scenarios.

1.2 Related Works

1.2.1 Linear Speedup Analyses of FedAvg Algorithms

Numerous variants of FedAvg have emerged in the literature since the groundbreaking study by McMahan et al. [6]. In these algorithms, the main feature lies in the local training strategies, which aim at mitigating the communication costs involved in FL. In the non-IID setting, the convergence rates of FedAvg have been established in [11] for problems satisfying the Polyak-Łojasiewicz condition, and in [12, 8] for general nonconvex problems. In the IID setting, the convergence of FedAvg algorithms has been studied in [7, 13, 14] for (strongly) convex problems, and in [15, 16, 13] for nonconvex problems. More complicated variants of FedAvg include [17], which employs momentum techniques to accelerate convergence, and [18], which incorporates control variates for variance reduction. The recent works by [19, 20] adopts a strategy that aggregates (possibly stale) stochastic gradients from all clients in each round. However, these approaches requires the server to wait for active clients to complete local computation using the current global model. While these algorithms achieve comparable convergence rates with linear speedup wrt the number of participating clients, they are all synchronous and rely on (a subset of) clients uploading up-to-date intermediate training results in each communication round. This makes them vulnerable to stragglers and essentially different from our DeFedAvg.

1.2.2 Asynchronous SGD Algorithms

There are various asynchronous variants of parallel SGD where clients operate at their own speeds without the need for synchronization, resulting in the server aggregating stale stochastic gradients. Under the IID setting, the linear speedup convergence of asynchronous SGD has been established in [21] for convex objectives, in [22, 23] for nonconvex objectives, and in [24] for convex quadratic objectives. In the non-IID setting, [25] achieves linear speedup by assuming identical staleness of the aggregated gradients. On the other hand, [26] provides the convergence analysis of asynchronous SGD for nonconvex objectives, while the linear speedup is not attained. It is worth noting that, unlike DeFedAvg (as well as FedAvg), asynchronous SGD methods involve clients solely responsible for gradient computation without performing local training. As a result, asynchronous SGD methods may require more frequent communication with the server compared to DeFedAvg.

1.2.3 AFL Algorithms

AFL algorithms share similarities with asynchronous SGD, while AFL generally involves local training on the clients. The recent work called FedBuff [27] has demonstrated the state-of-the-art empirical performance in AFL under non-IID data. It adopts a similar strategy to our DeFedAvg, where the server’s iteration occurs only when a specific subset of clients’ delayed updates arrive. However, unlike the uniform client sampling in DeFedAvg-nIID, FedBuff caches local updates from any n𝑛n active clients in each round. Based on the FedBuff framework, another AFL algorithm that caches all clients’ historical updates was proposed in [28]. While the convergence rate of this algorithm seems to achieve linear speedup, its theoretical analysis is intrinsically based on highly demanding assumptions. We will delve into a further discussion on this matter in Section 3. In several other works on AFL, such as [29, 30, 31], the server immediately updates the global model upon receiving a local model from a client; while in the most recently proposed AFL algorithms, called QuAFL [32] and FAVANO [33], a different asynchrony model is adopted, where the server can interrupt the clients to request their intermediate local updates. Besides, there is another line of research on AFL that focuses on the semi-decentralized edge systems [34, 35]. Although the existing papers on AFL generally provide convergence analyses on nonconvex problems, the linear speedup property has still not been rigorously attained under standard assumptions.

2 Delayed Federated Averaging

In this paper, we focus on the situations in which the N𝑁N clients are heterogeneous and can communicate with the central server without peer-to-peer communication.

FedAvg has garnered great interest in the field of FL lately, and there exist a batch of distributed algorithms in the literature that can be seen as variants of FedAvg, e.g., [36, 37, 7, 13, 18, 8, 38, 39]. The general principle of FedAvg algorithms lies in performing iterations for multiple steps with the local data at the clients, and then aggregating the model updates at the central server. Here, let us recap a generic version of FedAvg that was introduced in [18, Section 3]. 2.1 DeFedAvg-nIID

We first introduce DeFedAvg-nIID for solving Problem (1) with non-IID local data distributions 𝒟1,…,𝒟Nsubscript𝒟1…subscript𝒟𝑁\mathcal{D}_{1},\dots,\mathcal{D}_{N}, which is common in most FL applications. We describe the pseudo-code of DeFedAvg-nIID in Algorithm 1, in which the clients and the server work in a parallel manner.

In the initial round t=0𝑡0t=0 of DeFedAvg-nIID, the server initializes a global model 𝒘0superscript𝒘0\bm{w}^{0} and broadcasts it to the receive buffers of all the clients. Each client fetches the global model 𝒘0superscript𝒘0\bm{w}^{0} from their receive buffer and perform parallel local training starting from 𝒘0superscript𝒘0\bm{w}^{0}. Within a general round t𝑡t (t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0), we elaborate Algorithm 2 in the following.

2.1.1 Clients’ Procedures

Once the receive buffer of a client is non-empty, it can retrieve the global model 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} (ignoring the superscript for now) from the receive buffer and commence local training using its local data. At the same time, the receive buffer may be updated with the server’s latest global model. The completed local model updates (which will be specified later) are then placed into the send buffer. As a result, each client perform asynchronous local training at its own pace without the needs to be selected by the server and synchronized with other clients.

Suppose that client i𝑖i is selected by the server at the beginning of round t𝑡t. The latest global model at the receive buffer is 𝒘tsuperscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}^{t}, while it is possible that the client’s local training has been initiated from a stale version of the global model, denoted by 𝒘τi​(t)superscript𝒘subscript𝜏𝑖𝑡\bm{w}^{\tau_{i}(t)}. Here, τi​(t)subscript𝜏𝑖𝑡\tau_{i}(t) is the round index of the global model that client i𝑖i has used in local training in round t𝑡t, and thus we have 0≤τi​(t)≤t0subscript𝜏𝑖𝑡𝑡0\leq\tau_{i}(t)\leq t. into the send buffer before uploading to the server.

2.1.2 Server’s Procedures

When the clients have diverse communication/computation speeds, the deterministic client participation scheme employed in many FL algorithms [40, 27] tends to favor fast clients, as the fast clients may dominate the global aggregation compared to the slow ones throughout the training process. This can result in a biased exploitation of the local information in Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}’s, potentially impeding the convergence of these algorithms. Therefore, we adopt a random client selection scheme in DeFedAvg-nIID, where the server samples clients uniformly with replacement n𝑛n independent times in each round. The selected clients upload their local updates if their send buffers are nonempty, while the remaining clients continue their ongoing work. We use ℐtsubscriptℐ𝑡\mathcal{I}_{t} to denote the random set of the selected clients in round t𝑡t. Since each client can be selected more than once, ℐtsubscriptℐ𝑡\mathcal{I}_{t} is a multiset that may contain repeated elements and |ℐt|≤nsubscriptℐ𝑡𝑛|\mathcal{I}_{t}|\leq n. Once the clients in ℐtsubscriptℐ𝑡\mathcal{I}_{t} have uploaded their local updates 𝚫itsuperscriptsubscript𝚫𝑖𝑡\bm{\Delta}_{i}^{t}’s, the server proceeds to create a new global model 𝒘t+1superscript𝒘𝑡1\bm{w}^{t+1} as follows:

𝒘t+1=𝒘t−η​𝒈nIIDt,superscript𝒘𝑡1superscript𝒘𝑡𝜂superscriptsubscript𝒈nIID𝑡\displaystyle\bm{w}^{t+1}=\bm{w}^{t}-\eta\bm{g}_{\textnormal{nIID}}^{t}, (6)

where η>0𝜂0\eta>0 is the global learning rate, 𝚫itsuperscriptsubscript𝚫𝑖𝑡\bm{\Delta}_{i}^{t} is client i𝑖i’s local update that will be specified later, and

𝒈nIIDt≔1|ℐt|​∑i∈ℐt𝚫it.≔superscriptsubscript𝒈nIID𝑡1subscriptℐ𝑡subscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝚫𝑖𝑡\displaystyle\bm{g}_{\textnormal{nIID}}^{t}\coloneqq\frac{1}{|\mathcal{I}_{t}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}}\bm{\Delta}_{i}^{t}. (7)

Then, 𝒘t+1superscript𝒘𝑡1\bm{w}^{t+1} is broadcast to all the N𝑁N clients’ receive buffers. As a result of formulas (4)–(7), the global iterations of the DeFedAvg-nIID algorithm can be expressed compactly as:

𝒘t+1=𝒘t−η​η¯n​∑i∈ℐt∑k=0K−1∇f​(𝒘iτi​(t),k;𝝃it,k)superscript𝒘𝑡1superscript𝒘𝑡𝜂¯𝜂𝑛subscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝝃𝑖𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\bm{w}^{t+1}=\bm{w}^{t}-\frac{\eta\bar{\eta}}{n}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\nabla f(\bm{w}_{i}^{\tau_{i}(t),k};\bm{\xi}_{i}^{t,k}) (8)

for t=0,1,…,T−1𝑡01…𝑇1t=0,1,\dots,T-1. In this iteration formula, the staleness in the aggregated gradients reflects the asynchrony property, and the uniform randomness in ℐtsubscriptℐ𝑡\mathcal{I}_{t} plays a crucial role in ensuring linear speedup with non-IID data.

2.2 DeFedAvg-IID

In this subsection, we consider the IID setting where each client has a local dataset that is representative of the overall population and thus the local loss functions are the same (Fi=Fjsubscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐹𝑗F_{i}=F_{j} for all i,j∈[N]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑁i,j\in[N]). In edge computing environments, clients such as sensors or cameras may be deployed in a controlled environment or have similar characteristics. For instance, in a smart city application where traffic monitoring cameras contribute to FL, the data collected from these cameras might be IID if they are installed in similar locations and conditions. Besides, in certain IoT applications, such as smart home clients or wearable devices produced by the same manufacturer, the data collected from these clients may exhibit similar patterns and characteristics. If the clients are part of a homogeneous group, the data distributions may be relatively consistent, assuming similar usage patterns.

While DeFedAvg-nIID can be applied to such a scenario, its uniform client sampling scheme is conservative because it may overlook faster clients that complete local training but are not selected by the server. Therefore, we develop DeFedAvg-IID to further enhance the system efficiency. Formally, we assume that the local data distribution 𝒟i≔𝒟≔subscript𝒟𝑖𝒟\mathcal{D}_{i}\coloneqq\mathcal{D} for all i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] with 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} supported on some sample space ΞΞ\Xi. Then, Problem (1) can be simplified as follows:

min𝒘∈ℝd⁡F​(𝒘)=𝔼𝝃∼𝒟​[f​(𝒘;𝝃)].subscript𝒘superscriptℝ𝑑𝐹𝒘subscript𝔼similar-to𝝃𝒟delimited-[]𝑓𝒘𝝃\displaystyle\min_{\bm{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F(\bm{w})=\mathbb{E}_{\bm{\xi}\sim\mathcal{D}}[f(\bm{w};\bm{\xi})]. (9)

The pseudo-code of DeFedAvg-IID is described in Algorithm 2. The warm-up phase of DeFedAvg-IID remains the same as described in Section 2.1, and we focus on the key distinctions in terms of the clients’ and the server’s procedures.

2.2.1 Clients’ Procedures

The clients’ local iteration formula of DeFedAvg-IID is the same as that of DeFedAvg-nIID given by (4), while the different thing is that the clients do not need to have send buffers. Once client i𝑖i’s local training is completed, the local model update 𝚫itsuperscriptsubscript𝚫𝑖𝑡\bm{\Delta}_{i}^{t} shall be directly sent to the server without being selected. Subsequently, if the receive buffer is nonempty, the client proceeds with new local training by fetching the latest global model from the receive buffer.

2.2.2 Server’s Procedures

In DeFedAvg-IID, the server does not actively sample clients randomly, while cache arbitrary n𝑛n clients’ local model updates that first arrive. On the one hand, the dominance of fast clients during the training process is not an issue, as the data samples from fast and slow clients are equally representative of the overall population. On the other hand, such an arbitrary client participation scheme fully exploits the computation/communication capability of fast clients, which potentially reduces the server’s waiting time in DeFedAvg-nIID. Formally speaking, we let Itsubscript𝐼𝑡I_{t} be the set of participating clients in round t𝑡t with |It|=nsubscript𝐼𝑡𝑛|I_{t}|=n. We remark that Itsubscript𝐼𝑡I_{t} does not contain randomness, in contrast to the random set ℐtsubscriptℐ𝑡\mathcal{I}_{t} (denoted in calligraphic) that was defined earlier. Similar to (6), the server creates a new global model 𝒘t+1superscript𝒘𝑡1\bm{w}^{t+1} as follows:

𝒘t+1=𝒘t−η​𝒈IIDt,superscript𝒘𝑡1superscript𝒘𝑡𝜂superscriptsubscript𝒈IID𝑡\displaystyle\bm{w}^{t+1}=\bm{w}^{t}-\eta\bm{g}_{\textnormal{IID}}^{t},

where η>0𝜂0\eta>0 is the global learning rate, 𝚫itsuperscriptsubscript𝚫𝑖𝑡\bm{\Delta}_{i}^{t} is client i𝑖i’s local model update that is same as (5), and 𝒈IIDt≔1|It|​∑i∈It𝚫it≔superscriptsubscript𝒈IID𝑡1subscript𝐼𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝐼𝑡superscriptsubscript𝚫𝑖𝑡\bm{g}_{\textnormal{IID}}^{t}\coloneqq\frac{1}{|I_{t}|}\sum_{i\in I_{t}}\bm{\Delta}_{i}^{t}. Then, 𝒘t+1superscript𝒘𝑡1\bm{w}^{t+1} is broadcast to all the N𝑁N clients’ receive buffers. The global iterations of DeFedAvg-IID can be compactly expressed as:

𝒘t+1=𝒘t−η​η¯n​∑i∈It∑k=0K−1f​(𝒘iτi​(t),k;𝝃it,k)superscript𝒘𝑡1superscript𝒘𝑡𝜂¯𝜂𝑛subscript𝑖subscript𝐼𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1𝑓superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝝃𝑖𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\bm{w}^{t+1}=\bm{w}^{t}-\frac{\eta\bar{\eta}}{n}\sum_{i\in I_{t}}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}f(\bm{w}_{i}^{\tau_{i}(t),k};\bm{\xi}_{i}^{t,k})

for t=0,1,…,T−1𝑡01…𝑇1t=0,1,\dots,T-1, which is same as (8) expect that the stale gradients are aggregated over non-random sets Itsubscript𝐼𝑡I_{t}.

2.3 Practical Issues of DeFedAvg.

Alike its synchronous FL counterparts [6, 8], DeFedAvg also adopts partial clinet participation schemes, which subsume the “full” client participation scheme as a special case by setting n=N𝑛𝑁n=N. In spite of the partial participation, DeFedAvg requires the server to broadcast the global model to all clients in each round. This is because all the clients need to use it for local training, regardless of whether they are selected or not. In many FL applications, the central server (e.g., a base station) has sufficient power supply and downlink bandwidth for broadcasting to all the clients (e.g., smartphones, autonomous vehicles). The clients typically have limited power supply and uplink bandwidth, while fortunately only unicast communication to the server is required in DeFedAvg.

When implementing DeFedAvg-nIID, each client is able to continuously execute local training using the the most recent global model in the receive buffer, so that the potential delay t−τi​(t)𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖𝑡t-\tau_{i}(t) can be minimal when the client is selected in a certain round t𝑡t. Using this strategy, a client may overwrites its send buffer if it generates multiple local model updates before being selected by the server. However, under the circumstances where the clients are energy-limited, we can let the send buffer be overwritten only when the client is sampled by the server. Indeed, both implementations enjoy the same theoretical property (see Theorems 1 and 2 in Section 3), while may differ in practical efficiency.

We present an intuitive comparison of clients’ local training protocols of FedAvg, DeFedAvg-nIID, and DeFedAvg-IID, as shown in Fig. 1. We assume that there are a total of N=3𝑁3N=3 clients, and in each round, only n=2𝑛2n=2 clients participate in the global update, and we ignore the communication time for the sake of simplicity. We can observe that the DeFedAvg algorithms effectively mitigate the straggler effect that is present in FedAvg by reducing the idle time during the training process. Furthermore, DeFedAvg-IID goes a step further by eliminating the cost associated with random client selection that exists in DeFedAvg-nIID. By using the ‘first-complete-first-upload’ pattern for client participation, DeFedAvg-IID achieves even faster training compared to DeFedAvg-nIID, while it is only suitable for the IID setting.

3 Theoretical Analyses

In this section, we establish the convergence rates and linear speedup of DeFedAvg-nIID and DeFedAvg-IID. We first introduce the following standard assumptions before presenting our theoretical results.

Assumption 1 (L𝐿L-smoothness).

There exists L>0𝐿0L>0 such that for all i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] and 𝐰,𝐰′∈ℝd𝐰superscript𝐰′superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{w},\bm{w}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

‖∇Fi​(𝒘)−∇Fi​(𝒘′)‖2≤L​‖𝒘−𝒘′‖2.subscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒘′2𝐿subscriptnorm𝒘superscript𝒘′2\displaystyle\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w})-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}^{\prime})\|_{2}\leq L\|\bm{w}-\bm{w}^{\prime}\|_{2}.
Assumption 2 (unbiased stochastic gradient).

Suppose that 𝛏i∈Ξisubscript𝛏𝑖subscriptΞ𝑖\bm{\xi}_{i}\in\Xi_{i} is a data sample, 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is a local/global iterate generated by DeFedAvg, and ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is a sigma algebra. If 𝐰𝐰\bm{w} is ℱℱ\mathcal{F}-measurable and 𝛏isubscript𝛏𝑖\bm{\xi}_{i} is independent of 𝐰𝐰\bm{w}, then for all i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N],

𝔼​[∇f​(𝒘;𝝃i)∣ℱ]=∇Fi​(𝒘).𝔼delimited-[]conditional∇𝑓𝒘subscript𝝃𝑖ℱ∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\nabla f(\bm{w};\bm{\xi}_{i})\mid\mathcal{F}]=\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}). (10)

Subtlety in Applying Assumption 2: Note that if 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} is random, then 𝔼𝝃i∼𝒟i​[∇f​(𝒘;𝝃i)]=𝔼​[∇f​(𝒘;𝝃i)|𝒘]≠∇Fi​(𝒘)subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝝃𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖delimited-[]∇𝑓𝒘subscript𝝃𝑖𝔼delimited-[]conditional∇𝑓𝒘subscript𝝃𝑖𝒘∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘\mathbb{E}_{\bm{\xi}_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}}[\nabla f(\bm{w};\bm{\xi}_{i})]=\mathbb{E}[\nabla f(\bm{w};\bm{\xi}_{i})|\bm{w}]\neq\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}) as the iterate 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} can be a function of (thus depend on) 𝝃isubscript𝝃𝑖\bm{\xi}_{i} in general. To ensure the unbiasedness property (10), we need the conditions that ℱℱ\mathcal{F} contains all information in 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} and 𝝃isubscript𝝃𝑖\bm{\xi}_{i} is independent of 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}. Due to the presence of delay in DeFedAvg, it is crucial to deal with the total expectation of the inner product term 𝔼​[⟨∇F​(𝒘t),∇f​(𝒘iτi​(t),k;𝝃it,k)⟩]𝔼delimited-[]∇𝐹superscript𝒘𝑡∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝝃𝑖𝑡𝑘\mathbb{E}\left[\left\langle\nabla F(\bm{w}^{t}),\nabla f(\bm{w}_{i}^{\tau_{i}(t),k};\bm{\xi}_{i}^{t,k})\right\rangle\right] in the theoretical analysis. It is worth emphasizing that we index the data sample 𝝃it,ksuperscriptsubscript𝝃𝑖𝑡𝑘\bm{\xi}_{i}^{t,k} by t𝑡t to highlight that all previous models 𝒘0,𝒘1,…,𝒘tsuperscript𝒘0superscript𝒘1…superscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}^{0},\bm{w}^{1},\dots,\bm{w}^{t} do not depend on it. Thus, applying the law of total expectation and Assumption 2 yields

𝔼​[⟨∇F​(𝒘t),∇f​(𝒘iτi​(t),k;𝝃it,k)⟩]𝔼delimited-[]∇𝐹superscript𝒘𝑡∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝝃𝑖𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathbb{E}\left[\left\langle\nabla F(\bm{w}^{t}),\nabla f(\bm{w}_{i}^{\tau_{i}(t),k};\bm{\xi}_{i}^{t,k})\right\rangle\right]
=\displaystyle= 𝔼[⟨∇F(𝒘t),𝔼[∇f(𝒘iτi​(t),k;𝝃it,k)|𝒘t,𝒘iτi​(t),k]⟩]\displaystyle\leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathbb{E}\left[\left\langle\nabla F(\bm{w}^{t}),\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla f(\bm{w}_{i}^{\tau_{i}(t),k};\bm{\xi}_{i}^{t,k})\leavevmode\nobreak\ \middle|\leavevmode\nobreak\ \bm{w}^{t},\bm{w}_{i}^{\tau_{i}(t),k}\right]\right\rangle\right]

which plays an important role in establishing the convergence rates and linear speedup (see the supplementary materials for further details). By contrast, some existing AFL algorithms [41, 42, 28] involve inner product terms of the form 𝔼​[⟨∇F​(𝒘t),∇f​(𝒘iτi​(t),k;𝝃is,k)⟩]𝔼delimited-[]∇𝐹superscript𝒘𝑡∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝝃𝑖𝑠𝑘\mathbb{E}\left[\left\langle\nabla F(\bm{w}^{t}),\nabla f(\bm{w}_{i}^{\tau_{i}(t),k};\bm{\xi}_{i}^{s,k})\right\rangle\right], where s<t𝑠𝑡s<t. Hence,

𝔼​[⟨∇F​(𝒘t),∇f​(𝒘iτi​(t),k;𝝃is,k)⟩]𝔼delimited-[]∇𝐹superscript𝒘𝑡∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝝃𝑖𝑠𝑘\displaystyle\leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathbb{E}\left[\left\langle\nabla F(\bm{w}^{t}),\nabla f(\bm{w}_{i}^{\tau_{i}(t),k};\bm{\xi}_{i}^{s,k})\right\rangle\right]
=\displaystyle= 𝔼[⟨∇F(𝒘t),𝔼[∇f(𝒘iτi​(t),k;𝝃is,k)|𝒘t,𝒘iτi​(t),k]⟩]\displaystyle\leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathbb{E}\left[\left\langle\nabla F(\bm{w}^{t}),\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla f(\bm{w}_{i}^{\tau_{i}(t),k};\bm{\xi}_{i}^{s,k})\leavevmode\nobreak\ \middle|\leavevmode\nobreak\ \bm{w}^{t},\bm{w}_{i}^{\tau_{i}(t),k}\right]\right\rangle\right]
≠\displaystyle\neq 𝔼​[⟨∇F​(𝒘t),∇Fi​(𝒘iτi​(t),k)⟩].𝔼delimited-[]∇𝐹superscript𝒘𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathbb{E}\left[\left\langle\nabla F(\bm{w}^{t}),\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i}^{\tau_{i}(t),k})\right\rangle\right].

This subtle yet fatal discrepancy might be overlooked by previous works, which poses a significant challenge to conduct rigorous convergence analyses of these algorithms under the standard unbiasedness Assumption 2.

Furthermore, we impose the following upper bounds on the conditional variance of stochastic gradients and maximum delay.

Assumption 3 (bounded variance).

Suppose that 𝛏i∈Ξisubscript𝛏𝑖subscriptΞ𝑖\bm{\xi}_{i}\in\Xi_{i} is a data sample, 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is a local/global iterate generated by DeFedAvg, and ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is a sigma algebra. If 𝐰𝐰\bm{w} is ℱℱ\mathcal{F}-measurable and 𝛏isubscript𝛏𝑖\bm{\xi}_{i} is independent of 𝐰𝐰\bm{w}, then there exists σ>0𝜎0\sigma>0 such that for all i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] and k=0,1,…,K−1𝑘01…𝐾1k=0,1,\dots,K-1,

𝔼​[‖∇f​(𝒘i;𝝃i)−∇Fi​(𝒘i)‖22∣ℱ]≤σ2.𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓subscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝝃𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖22ℱsuperscript𝜎2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\|\nabla f(\bm{w}_{i};\bm{\xi}_{i})-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i})\|_{2}^{2}\mid\mathcal{F}\right]\leq\sigma^{2}.
Assumption 4 (bounded delay).

There exists an integer λ≥1𝜆1{\lambda}\geq 1 such that for all i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] and t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0,

τi​(t)≥(t−λ)+,subscript𝜏𝑖𝑡subscript𝑡𝜆\tau_{i}(t)\geq(t-{\lambda})_{+},

where (x)+≔max⁡{x,0}≔subscript𝑥𝑥0(x)_{+}\coloneqq\max\{x,0\} for x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}.

Assumption 4 is common in distributed learning using stale gradients, e.g., [22, 27], which indicates that the clients can be arbitrarily delayed as long as they participate in the global iterations at least once in the last λ𝜆{\lambda} rounds. For Algorithm 2, the value of λ𝜆\lambda is a system attribute that is determined by the computation/communication time of the clients and the server. For Algorithm 1, due to the randomness in client sampling, there is a chance (albeit tiny) that a client is not selected throughout the training process and thus Assumption 4 is violated. Indeed, according to [19, Theorem 5.2], it holds with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta that λ≤𝒪​(1p​(1+log⁡N​Tδ))𝜆𝒪1𝑝1𝑁𝑇𝛿\lambda\leq\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{p}\left(1+\log\frac{NT}{\delta}\right)\right), where p=1−(N−1N)n𝑝1superscript𝑁1𝑁𝑛p=1-\left(\frac{N-1}{N}\right)^{n} is the probability of each client being sampled in a single round. In other words, the maximum delay λ𝜆{\lambda} in DeFedAvg-nIID exhibits mild logarithmic dependence on the total number of communication rounds T𝑇T with high probability.

3.1 Linear Speedup of DeFedAvg-nIID

Since DeFedAvg-nIID applies to Problem (1) with different local objective functions, we impose the following upper bound on the heterogeneity of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}’s:

Assumption 5 (bounded heterogeneity).

Suppose that 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is a local/global iterate generated by Algorithm 1. Then, there exists ν≥0𝜈0\nu\geq 0 such that for all i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N],

𝔼​‖∇Fi​(𝒘)−∇F​(𝒘)‖22≤ν2.𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘∇𝐹𝒘22superscript𝜈2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w})-\nabla F(\bm{w})\|_{2}^{2}\leq\nu^{2}.

Moreover, we assume the uniform upper bound on the expected gradient norm squares:

Assumption 6 (bounded gradient).

Suppose that 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is a local/global iterate generated by Algorithm 1. Then, there exists G≥0𝐺0G\geq 0 such that for all i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N],

𝔼​‖∇Fi​(𝒘)‖22≤G2.𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘22superscript𝐺2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w})\|_{2}^{2}\leq G^{2}.

Now, we are ready to present the following convergence rate of DeFedAvg-nIID:

Theorem 1.

Suppose that Assumptions 1–6 hold and

η¯≤18​L​K​and​η​η¯≤min⁡{14​L​K​λ,2​σ2+G2​K8​σ2​L​K​λ+4​L​G2​K2​λ2}.¯𝜂18𝐿𝐾and𝜂¯𝜂14𝐿𝐾𝜆2superscript𝜎2superscript𝐺2𝐾8superscript𝜎2𝐿𝐾𝜆4𝐿superscript𝐺2superscript𝐾2superscript𝜆2\displaystyle\bar{\eta}\leq\frac{1}{8LK}\hskip 0.56905pt\text{and}\hskip 2.84526pt\eta\bar{\eta}\leq\min\left\{\frac{1}{4LK\lambda},\frac{2\sigma^{2}+G^{2}K}{8\sigma^{2}LK\lambda+4LG^{2}K^{2}{\lambda}^{2}}\right\}. (11)

Then, it holds for T≥1𝑇1T\geq 1 that

1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼​‖∇F​(𝒘t)‖22≤1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐹superscript𝒘𝑡22absent\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla F(\bm{w}^{t})\|_{2}^{2}\leq 256​(F​(𝒘0)−F∗)​(16​σ2​L+8​L​G2​K)n​K​T256𝐹superscript𝒘0superscript𝐹16superscript𝜎2𝐿8𝐿superscript𝐺2𝐾𝑛𝐾𝑇\displaystyle\sqrt{\frac{256(F(\bm{w}^{0})-F^{*})(16\sigma^{2}L+8LG^{2}K)}{nKT}}

The proof of Theorem 1 is provided in the supplementary materials. On the one hand, the global learning rate η𝜂\eta given by Theorem 1 is positively correlated with F​(𝒘0)−F∗𝐹superscript𝒘0superscript𝐹F(\bm{w}^{0})-F^{*}. On the other hand, the local learning rate η¯¯𝜂\bar{\eta} is negatively correlated with the gradient’s variance bound σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, meaning that the noisier the local gradient is, the smaller the local learning rate should be to avoid “client drift” [18].

As a consequence of condition (11), we need T≥Ω​(n​K​λ4)𝑇Ω𝑛𝐾superscript𝜆4T\geq\Omega(nK\lambda^{4}). Therefore, the bound (12) indicates that the average squared gradient norm converges to zero at a rate of 𝒪​(1/n​T+1/K​T)𝒪1𝑛𝑇1𝐾𝑇\mathcal{O}({1}/{\sqrt{nT}}+1/KT) for sufficiently large T𝑇T. In other words, to ensure that 1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼​|∇F​(𝒘t)|22≤ϵ1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼superscriptsubscript∇𝐹superscript𝒘𝑡22italic-ϵ\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}|\nabla F(\bm{w}^{t})|_{2}^{2}\leq\epsilon, the total number of communication rounds required scales as 𝒪​(1/n​ϵ2+1/K​ϵ)𝒪1𝑛superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝐾italic-ϵ\mathcal{O}(1/n\epsilon^{2}+1/K\epsilon). This scaling is inversely proportional to the number of participating clients n𝑛n for sufficiently small ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, indicating linear speedup with respect to n𝑛n. In essence, as the number of participating clients increases, the required number of communication rounds decreases, leading to improved convergence rates and overall efficiency in FL.

When we set λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1, indicating no delay in the updates, Theorem 1 aligns with the existing result for synchronous FedAvg for FL with non-IID data. Specifically, it has been shown in [8] that the FedAvg converges at a rate of 𝒪​(K/n​T+1/T)𝒪𝐾𝑛𝑇1𝑇\mathcal{O}({\sqrt{K}}/{\sqrt{nT}}+1/T) when T=Ω​(n​K)𝑇Ω𝑛𝐾T=\Omega(nK) for solving Problem (1). This observation highlights that the delay in local training does not hinder the asymptotic convergence rate when compared to synchronous FedAvg.

Consider the special case when K=1𝐾1K=1, then DeFedAvg-nIID reduces to an asynchronous SGD algorithm, and Theorem 1 implies a 𝒪​(1/n​T+1/T)𝒪1𝑛𝑇1𝑇\mathcal{O}({1}/{\sqrt{nT}}+1/T) convergence rate for T=Ω​(n​λ4)𝑇Ω𝑛superscript𝜆4T=\Omega(n\lambda^{4}). We notice that [26] has established the best-known convergence rate of 𝒪​(1/T+1/T)𝒪1𝑇1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}+1/T) for asynchronous SGD under the same setting without the bounded gradient assumption, while the linear speedup property remains unclear. Our result, as far as we know, provides the first linear speedup guarantee of asynchronous SGD with non-IID data, which can be of independent interest.

DeFedAvg-nIID is most analogous to the FedBuff AFL algorithm [27], which also adopts asynchronous local training and partial participation schemes. Differently, FedBuff caches local updates from any n𝑛n active clients in each round. Such a deterministic client participation scheme favors fast clients and thus may impede convergence under the heterogeneous setting. This issue is also evidenced by the theoretical analysis in [27, Section D], which has to make a rather demanding assumption that all clients participate with equal probability so as to guarantee the convergence rate of 𝒪​(1/K​T+K/(n2​T)+λ2/T)𝒪1𝐾𝑇𝐾superscript𝑛2𝑇superscript𝜆2𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{KT}+K/(n^{2}T)+\lambda^{2}/T), without achieving asymptotic linear speedup wrt n𝑛n.

3.2 Linear Speedup of DeFedAvg-IID

Now, we present the following convergence rate of DeFedAvg-IID:

Theorem 2.

Let F∗∈ℝsuperscript𝐹ℝF^{*}\in\mathbb{R} be the optimal function value of Problem (9), 𝐰0∈ℝdsuperscript𝐰0superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{w}^{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} be the initial global model of Algorithm 2, and {𝐰t}t≥1subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝑡1\{\bm{w}^{t}\}_{t\geq 1} be the sequence of global models generated by Algorithm 2 for solving Problem (9). Let η=n​K​(F​(𝐰0)−F∗)/2𝜂𝑛𝐾𝐹superscript𝐰0superscript𝐹2\eta=\sqrt{nK(F(\bm{w}^{0})-F^{*})/2} and η¯=1/σ2​L​T​K¯𝜂1superscript𝜎2𝐿𝑇𝐾\bar{\eta}=1/\sqrt{\sigma^{2}LT}K. Suppose that Assumptions 1–4 hold and

η¯≤14​3​L​K​and​η​η¯≤14​L​K​λ.¯𝜂143𝐿𝐾and𝜂¯𝜂14𝐿𝐾𝜆\displaystyle\bar{\eta}\leq\frac{1}{4\sqrt{3}LK}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \text{and}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \eta\bar{\eta}\leq\frac{1}{4LK{\lambda}}. (13)

Then, it holds for T≥1𝑇1T\geq 1 that

1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼​‖∇F​(𝒘t)‖221𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐹superscript𝒘𝑡22\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla F(\bm{w}^{t})\|_{2}^{2} ≤128​(F​(𝒘0)−F∗)n​K​T+8​LK​T.absent128𝐹superscript𝒘0superscript𝐹𝑛𝐾𝑇8𝐿𝐾𝑇\displaystyle\leq\sqrt{\frac{128(F(\bm{w}^{0})-F^{*})}{nKT}}+\frac{8L}{KT}. (14)

The proof of Theorem 2 is also deferred to the supplementary materials. Note that condition (13) implies a lower bound on the required number of global rounds T≥Ω​(n​K​λ2)𝑇Ω𝑛𝐾superscript𝜆2T\geq\Omega(nK\lambda^{2}), which exhibits a relaxed dependence on λ𝜆\lambda compared to the lower bound implied by Theorem 1. Inequality (14) suggests that the average gradient norm converges to zero at a rate of 𝒪​(1/n​K​T+1/K​T)𝒪1𝑛𝐾𝑇1𝐾𝑇\mathcal{O}({1}/{\sqrt{nKT}}+1/KT) as T𝑇T is sufficiently large. In other words, the total number of communication rounds required scales as 𝒪​(1/n​K​ϵ2+1/K​ϵ)𝒪1𝑛𝐾superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝐾italic-ϵ\mathcal{O}(1/nK\epsilon^{2}+1/K\epsilon) so that 1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼​‖∇F​(𝒘t)‖22≤ϵ1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐹superscript𝒘𝑡22italic-ϵ\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla F(\bm{w}^{t})\|_{2}^{2}\leq\epsilon, which also indicates linear speedup wrt to n𝑛n.

When λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1, indicating no delay in the updates, Theorem 2 implies a rate of 𝒪​(1/n​K​T+n/T)𝒪1𝑛𝐾𝑇𝑛𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{nKT}+n/T) provided that T=Ω​(n​K)𝑇Ω𝑛𝐾T=\Omega(nK), which aligns with the convergence rate of synchronous FedAvg presented in [13].

When K=1𝐾1K=1, indicating no local training, the convergence bound (14) reduces to the result for AsySG (an asynchronous SGD algorithm for IID data) [22] up to a high-order term. This result demonstrates that the asynchronous SGD converges at a rate of 𝒪​(1/n​T)𝒪1𝑛𝑇\mathcal{O}({1}/{\sqrt{nT}}) when T=Ω​(n​λ2)𝑇Ω𝑛superscript𝜆2T=\Omega(n{\lambda}^{2}). Besides, it is worth noting that condition (14) implies that K=𝒪​(T/n​λ2)𝐾𝒪𝑇𝑛superscript𝜆2K=\mathcal{O}(T/n{\lambda}^{2}). Consequently, if the number of local steps K𝐾K is not excessively large, the communication complexity decreases linearly as K𝐾K increases. This highlights the advantage of local training in DeFedAvg-IID, as it asymptotically reduces the number of communication rounds by a factor of 1/K1𝐾1/K while maintaining the same sample complexity as asynchronous SGD.

Furthermore, we notice that there is a similar asynchronous FedAvg algorithm mentioned in [7, Section 5] for solving Problem (9) with strongly convex objectives. Different from our DeFedAvg-IID, the algorithm in [7] has varying local steps K𝐾K across clients, the local learning rates diminish to 0, and there is no global learning rate. The algorithm in [7] attains 𝒪​(1/n​T)𝒪1𝑛𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/nT) convergence rate, while this result is limited to strongly convex objectives under the bounded gradient assumption. In contrast, Theorem 2 applies to general nonconvex problems without requiring bounded gradients. This sheds light on the distributed training of nonconvex deep neural networks, showcasing the applicability and effectiveness of DeFedAvg-IID in the more challenging setting.

4 Experiments

4.1 Experimental Setup

To validate the efficacy of our proposed method, we apply DeFedAvg to train deep neural networks with two convolutional layers and two fully connected layers under the FL scenario. Specifically, we simulate the collaborative training process of N=100𝑁100N=100 clients with diverse processing capabilities, and evaluate the algorithm performance on image classification tasks using the FashionMNIST [43] and CIFAR-10 [44] datasets.

Under the non-IID setting, we implement the (synchronous) FedAvg (2)–(3), FedBuff [27], and the recent AFL algorithm FAVANO [33] for comparisons with DeFedAvg-nIID. To introduce statistical heterogeneity in the non-IID setting, we randomly assign two classes of data to each client. This distribution of data among clients helps create a scenario where the training data across clients differ, thereby increasing the challenge of achieving convergence in the FL process.

Under the IID setting, we implement the FedAvg given by (2)–(3), FAVANO [33], and AsySG [22] for comparisons with DeFedAvg-IID. Each client is equipped with training data containing all classes. This ensures that the data distribution across clients is statistically homogeneous.

4.1.1 Neural Network Architecture

We adopt a convolutional neural network, which contains two 5×5555\times 5 convolutional layers followed by 2×2222\times 2 max pooling layers and two fully connected layers with the latent dimensions being 160016001600 and 512512512, respectively.

4.1.2 Evaluation Metrics

The direct evaluation metric for assessing convergence performance is the number of communication rounds required to reach a target optimization accuracy. However, it is important to note that in scenarios where the computation or communication speeds of different clients vary significantly, the actual runtime of a global round can differ considerably across different algorithms. In light of this, it is more reasonable to evaluate the practical performance using wall-clock time, which encompasses both computation time and communication time. This approach provides a more comprehensive assessment of the overall efficiency of the algorithms in real-world scenarios.

4.1.3 System Model

To measure the wall-clock time, we take into account both the computational time for local training at clients and the communication time for downloading the global model and uploading the local model updates.

Following the approach described in [35], we assume that the average time for local training can be represented as Tcomp=NMAC/CMACsubscript𝑇compsubscript𝑁MACsubscript𝐶MACT_{\text{comp}}=N_{\text{MAC}}/C_{\text{MAC}}, where NMACsubscript𝑁MACN_{\text{MAC}} denotes the number of floating-point operations required for one-iteration training and CMACsubscript𝐶MACC_{\text{MAC}} denotes the computation speed of the fastest client, set to be 10GFLOPS. For our experiments, the cost of updating the local models for one iteration using a mini-batch of ten samples is estimated to be 17.0MFLOPs for FashionMNIST and 31.4MFLOPs for CIFAR-10, respectively. Based on these values, we can calculate the computation time required for local training. To simulate the hardware heterogeneity, we assume that the computation speeds of clients follow the uniform distribution over interval [1,5]15[1,5], where the slowest client is five times slower than the fastest one. This variation in computation speeds allows us to capture the realistic heterogeneity in real-world FL systems.

Furthermore, we assume that the clients transmit the global model and local updates using a 5G network with a transmission bandwidth of 400Mbps for both the downlink and uplink. The model sizes for communication between clients and the server are estimated to be 2.2MB for FashionMNIST and 3.53MB for CIFAR-10, respectively. Based on these values, we can compute the communication time between the server and clients. It is worth noting that although we set the same communication time for all clients, the varying computation capabilities of the clients are sufficient to reflect the impact of system heterogeneity. The computational heterogeneity among clients has a significant influence on the overall performance, even when assuming the same communication time for all clients.

4.1.4 Hyperparameter Selection

For all the experiments, the value of the global learning rate η𝜂\eta (respectively, the local learning rate η¯¯𝜂\bar{\eta}) is selected from the set {0.1,1.0}0.11.0\{0.1,1.0\} (respectively, {0.001,0.005,0.01,0.05,0.1}0.0010.0050.010.050.1\{0.001,0.005,0.01,0.05,0.1\}). We report the numerical results based on the learning rates that yield the best convergence performance (note that the AsySG algorithm does not have a local learning rate). In all of the experiments, we utilize a total of N=100𝑁100N=100 clients to simulate the FL scenarios. Unless otherwise specified, each client performs local iterations with K=50𝐾50K=50 using the mini-batch SGD with a fixed batch size of 101010 in each step. We repeat all the experiments with three different random seeds and report the average results.

4.2 Numerical Results

The experiment results and their associated discussions are provided in the following.

4.2.1 Comparisons of Convergence Performance

Fig. 2 depicts the convergence of DeFedAvg and its counterparts over wall-clock time for n=10𝑛10n=10. It is observed that DeFedAvg consistently demonstrates the most rapid decrease in training losses and increase in test accuracies. In the non-IID case, FedAvg faces similar challenges due to the presence of straggler clients. On the other hand, while FedBuff allows for asynchronous training, it appears to be more prone to weak generalization. This could be because its training process heavily relies on fast clients, while the datasets at slower clients make relatively smaller contributions. By contrast, DeFedAvg-nIID enables uniform client sampling, which helps mitigate the problem by ensuring a balanced contribution from all clients. Additionally, when combined with delayed local training, DeFedAvg-nIID achieves faster convergence compared to other competitors. In the IID case, FedAvg is dragged down by the straggler clients due to the synchronization in each round, while AsySG necessitates frequent communication between clients and the server in the absence of local training. In comparison, the performance of DeFedAvg-IID is enhanced by leveraging both asynchronous updates and local iterations.

In addition to Fig. 2, we provide numerical results of the compared algorithms for n=20,40𝑛2040n=20,40, and 808080, as shown in Figures 3, 4, and 5, respectively. The results demonstrate that our proposed DeFedAvg algorithms are scalable as the number of participating clients n𝑛n increases. In all the experiments, DeFedAvg exhibits superior performance in terms of training losses and test accuracies.

We also compare the wall-clock time of the considered algorithms to reach the target test accuracies for different numbers of participating clients n𝑛n. As reported in Table I, DeFedAvg uses substantially less time than other algorithms in all cases. For instance, in the IID setting with n=10𝑛10n=10 on CIFAR-10, the time used for DeFedAvg-IID to reach 70%percent7070\% accuracy is almost 1/5 of that for FedAvg, demonstrating the effectiveness of asynchronous updates in DeFedAvg-IID. In the non-IID settings, FedBuff spends less time than the FedAvg when n𝑛n is small, while the advantage diminishes as n𝑛n increases.

4.2.2 Impact of n𝑛n in DeFedAvg

We explore the impact of the number of participating clients n𝑛n on the convergence behavior of our proposed DeFedAvg algorithms. In principle, increasing n𝑛n enhances the system parallelism (leading to less communication rounds) while reduces the client asynchronism (incurring less waiting time). On the contrary, decreasing n𝑛n reduces the system parallelism while enhances the client asynchronism. The results, as depicted in Fig. 6, demonstrate that increasing the number of participating clients expedites the convergence rates of DeFedAvg, which supports the convergence results presented in Theorems 1 and 2. The reason behind this phenomenon is that a larger value of n𝑛n allows for a more accurate estimation of the full gradient during global updates, thereby facilitating faster convergence over the communication rounds. Conversely, when n𝑛n is small, there is greater variance in the aggregated stochastic gradients, resulting in slower convergence rates and more oscillations in the performance curves.

4.2.3 Impact of K𝐾K in DeFedAvg

We conduct performance testing of DeFedAvg with varying values of local steps K𝐾K. Specifically, we select K=20,50,100𝐾2050100K=20,50,100, and the convergence results over communication rounds are presented in Fig. 7. As the value of K𝐾K increases, we observe that DeFedAvg-nIID demonstrates faster convergence rates. This behavior can potentially be attributed to the non-dominant term in the convergence bound (12), which has an order of 𝒪​(1/K​T)𝒪1𝐾𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/KT) and is inversely proportional to K𝐾K. Likewise, DeFedAvg-IID displays a similar pattern when K𝐾K increases, thereby supporting the discussion in Sections 3.2 regarding the impact of local steps on convergence. Moreover, we notice a decrease in the test accuracies on the CIFAR-10 dataset when K=100𝐾100K=100. This observation suggests that increasing the number of local steps may not always result in improved generalization performance.

5 Conclusion

This paper introduces the DeFedAvg framework to address the straggler effect in FedAvg under system heterogeneity, by enabling asynchronous local training while utilizing receive/send buffers across clients. Theoretical analyses demonstrate that DeFedAvg convergences at asymptotic rates comparable to its synchronous counterparts, and first provably achieves the linear speedup property in AFL, indicating its scalability potential. The algorithmic and theoretical frameworks presented in this paper hold promise for application and extension to other FL problems. For example, they are likely applicable in addressing challenges in client-edge-cloud hierarchical FL [45], client dropout problems [46, 47], semi-decentralized AFL [35], coded FL [48], federated knowledge distillation [49], over-the-air FL [50], etc. By leveraging the insights from DeFedAvg, these methods can benefit from efficient asynchronous training, potentially improving their performance and scalability.

Appendix A Proofs of Theorems

In this appendix, we provide the proofs of Theorems 1 and 2. To begin with, we introduce two facts that will be frequently used.

Fact 1.

Let U𝑈U and V𝑉V be two random variables, and ℱℱ\mathcal{F} be a sigma algebra. If U𝑈U is ℱℱ\mathcal{F}-measurable, then we have

𝔼​[U​V]=𝔼​[U​𝔼​[V|ℱ]].𝔼delimited-[]𝑈𝑉𝔼delimited-[]𝑈𝔼delimited-[]conditional𝑉ℱ\mathbb{E}[UV]=\mathbb{E}[U\mathbb{E}[V|\mathcal{F}]].
Proof.

Since U𝑈U is ℱℱ\mathcal{F}-measurable, we have

𝔼​[U​V|ℱ]=U​𝔼​[V|ℱ].𝔼delimited-[]conditional𝑈𝑉ℱ𝑈𝔼delimited-[]conditional𝑉ℱ\mathbb{E}[UV|\mathcal{F}]=U\mathbb{E}[V|\mathcal{F}].

Then, it follows from the law of total expectation that

𝔼​[U​V]=𝔼​[𝔼​[U​V|ℱ]]=𝔼​[U​𝔼​[V|ℱ]],𝔼delimited-[]𝑈𝑉𝔼delimited-[]𝔼delimited-[]conditional𝑈𝑉ℱ𝔼delimited-[]𝑈𝔼delimited-[]conditional𝑉ℱ\mathbb{E}[UV]=\mathbb{E}[\mathbb{E}[UV|\mathcal{F}]]=\mathbb{E}[U\mathbb{E}[V|\mathcal{F}]],

as desired. ∎

Fact 2.

Suppose that m≥2𝑚2m\geq 2 is an integer and 𝐱1,…,𝐱msubscript𝐱1…subscript𝐱𝑚\bm{x}_{1},\dots,\bm{x}_{m} are vectors in the same inner product space. Then, the following inequality holds:

‖∑i=1m𝒙i‖22≤m​∑i=1m‖𝒙i‖22.superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝒙𝑖22𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝒙𝑖22\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{m}\bm{x}_{i}\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq m\sum_{i=1}^{m}\|\bm{x}_{i}\|_{2}^{2}.

For notational convenience in the sequel, we define 𝑮it≔𝑮it≔superscriptsubscript𝑮𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑮𝑖𝑡\bm{G}_{i}^{t}\coloneqq\bm{G}_{i}^{t}, 𝑮it,k≔∇Fi​(𝒘iτi​(t),k)≔superscriptsubscript𝑮𝑖𝑡𝑘∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖𝑡𝑘\bm{G}_{i}^{t,k}\coloneqq\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}_{i}^{\tau_{i}(t),k}), and 𝒈it,k≔f​(𝒘iτi​(t),k;𝝃it,k)≔superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑖𝑡𝑘𝑓superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝝃𝑖𝑡𝑘\bm{g}_{i}^{t,k}\coloneqq f(\bm{w}_{i}^{\tau_{i}(t),k};\bm{\xi}_{i}^{t,k}) for i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] and t,k∈ℕ𝑡𝑘ℕt,k\in\mathbb{N}. We use 𝔼X​[⋅]subscript𝔼𝑋delimited-[]⋅\mathbb{E}_{X}[\cdot] to denote the conditional expectation by taking expectation wrt X𝑋X while holding other variables constant.

Lemma 2.

Suppose that Assumptions 2, 3, and 4 hold, and ℐt={j1t,…,jnt}subscriptℐ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝑗𝑛𝑡\mathcal{I}_{t}=\{j_{1}^{t},\dots,j_{n}^{t}\} is a multiset whose elements are independently and uniformly sampled from [N]delimited-[]𝑁[N] with replacement in round t𝑡t (t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0) of Algorithm 1.
